Use of Non-GAAP Financial Measures We have provided in this press release certain financial information that has not been prepared in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles in the United States (“GAAP”).  Our management uses these non-GAAP financial measures internally in analyzing our financial results and believes that use of these non-GAAP financial measures is useful to investors as an additional tool to evaluate ongoing operating results and trends and in comparing our financial results with other companies in our industry
column156: many of which present similar non-GAAP financial measures.  Non-GAAP financial measures are not meant to be considered in isolation or as a substitute for comparable financial measures prepared in accordance with GAAP and should be read only in conjunction with our consolidated financial statements prepared in accordance with GAAP.  A reconciliation of our historical non-GAAP financial measures to the most directly comparable GAAP measures has been provided in the financial statement tables included in this press release
column157: and investors are encouraged to review these reconciliations.  Annual revenue run-rate We calculate annual revenue run-rate (“ARR”) at the end of each month as the sum of: (1) the product of the current month’s monthly recurring revenue (“MRR”) multiplied by twelve (to prospectively annualize subscription revenue)
column158: and (2) the trailing twelve-month partner and services revenue
column160: such as one-time partner integration fees and store-launch services.  MRR includes BigCommerce platform subscription fees and invoiced growth adjustments as customers’ businesses grow past contracted order thresholds after a threshold has been met.  It also includes recurring professional services revenue
column161: such as recurring technical account management services and product training services.  Accounts with greater than $2
column162: 000 ACV We track the total number of accounts with annual contract value (“ACV”) greater than $2
column163: 000 (the “ACV threshold”) as of the end of a monthly billing period.  To define this $2
column165: we include only subscription plan revenue and exclude partner and services revenue and recurring services revenue.  We consider all stores added and subtracted as of the end of the monthly billing period.  This metric includes accounts that may have either one single store above the ACV threshold or multiple stores that together exceed the ACV threshold.  Accordingly
column166: this cohort would include: (1) customers on Enterprise plans
column168: and (3) customers with multiple plans that together exceed the ACV threshold.  Average revenue per account We calculate average revenue per account (ARPA) for accounts above the ACV threshold at the end of a period by including customer-billed revenue and an allocation of partner and services revenue.  Adjusted EBITDA We define Adjusted EBITDA as our net loss
column169: excluding the impact of stock-based compensation expense and related payroll tax expense
column173: changes in fair value of financial instruments
column174: and our provision for income taxes.  The most directly comparable GAAP measure is net loss.  Non-GAAP Operating Loss We define Non-GAAP Operating Loss as our GAAP Loss from operations
column175: excluding the impact of stock-based compensation expense and related payroll tax expense.  The most directly comparable GAAP measure is our loss from operations.  Non-GAAP Net Loss We define Non-GAAP Net Loss as our GAAP net loss
column176: excluding the impact of stock-based compensation expense and related payroll tax expense.  The most directly comparable GAAP measure is our net loss.  Non-GAAP Net Loss per Share We define Non-GAAP Net Loss per Share as our Non-GAAP Net Loss
column178: divided by our basic and diluted GAAP weighted average shares outstanding.  The most directly comparable GAAP measure is our net loss per share.  Free Cash Flow We define Free Cash flow as our GAAP cash flow from operating activities plus our GAAP purchases of property and equipment (Capital Expenditures).  The most directly comparable GAAP measure is our cash flow from operating activities. column3: to be exact.  Yet the cards have been spotted in online stores all across the map early
column4: and it wouldn't be surprising to hear people are rushing to snatch them up. According to VideoCardz
column5: a seller named Artem had three Gigabyte Eagle RTX 3060 cards on sale in Belarusian store Onliner over the weekend.  The sale page has since disappeared
column7: but I'd bet these cards sold for their listing price of $1
column8: 080 each (in USD equivalent cash).  That is
column9: if they weren't pulled beforehand. What's really funny about this listing is that these sale images clearly show the serial numbers.  That makes it a doddle for Gigabyte to trace the cards and find out exactly where they slipped off the truck. column1: 2021-02-22 21:19:09#tech#Activision details Call of Duty: Black Ops - Cold War's new Zombies Outbreak mode#https://www.pcgamer.com/activision-details-how-call-of-duty-cold-wars-zombies-outbreak-mode-will-actually-work/#https://cdn.mos.cms.futurecdn.net/tY52XpHSw4bbjJu4BWxp2N-1200-80.jpg#en#0.0#www.pcgamer.com#"Last week
column2: Activision revealed that a ""large-scale"" Zombies mode called Outbreak is coming to Season Two of Call of Duty: Black Ops—Cold War.  Today it dropped a trailer showcasing the new mode in action
column3: along with a blog post detailing how it's all going to work. The trailer isn't much to write home about
column4: I don't think: Gunfire
column7: and generic one-liners delivered flatly by voice actors who sound like they're reading from the phone book
column8: while a classic rock remix plays in the background.  The blog post is a different story
column9: however.  There's plenty of narrative background if you're into that sort of thing
column10: and more practically there's also a breakdown of how the new mode will actually play. Squads of up to four players will be inserted into the Outbreak zone and given one of five objectives to investigate and complete.  How you approach these objectives is entirely up to you: You can take any route to get there
column11: and as much time as you like along the way.  Exploring the region will uncover rewards in loot chests
column13: and open up Trial Computers. More types of missions are expected to be added as Outbreak grows and evolves
column15: this is what you'll be getting up to:"#https://www.pcgamer.com/activision-details-how-call-of-duty-cold-wars-zombies-outbreak-mode-will-actually-work/#ewwo6OIuk

column32: Don Wycherley (“Wild Mountain Thyme”) and Jeena Yi (“Unbreakable Kimmy Schmidt”).  Inspired by the popular column of the same name in The New York Times
column33: “Modern Love” is described as exploring love “in all of its complicated and beautiful forms. ” Each standalone episode tells a story from a different column entry.  The first season premiered in October 2019 and it was quickly renewed for Season 2 by Amazon.  Also Read: Amazon Renews 'Modern Love' for Season 2
column34: Signs Overall Deal With Showrunner John Carney According to the streaming service
column35: the second season was filmed in Albany
column42: executive producer and showrunner on the series.  Additionally
column44: Marta Cunningham (“Insecure”) Jesse Peretz (“Glow”) and Andrew Rannells (“Black Monday”) will also direct episodes of the anthology series with Celine Held and Logan George (“Topside”) co-directing an episode.  The episode Rannells will direct is based upon a personal essay that he penned for the New York Times column.  “We’re so excited to bring a second season of this series to life
column45: and give an opportunity to really shine a light on what matters most
column46: ” Carney said.  “With so much uncertainty in our current world
column47: these stories bring truth and love to people everywhere
column48: and I’m so appreciative to be a part of making that happen. ” Also Read: 'Modern Love' Trailer: Tina Fey and John Slattery Spend Date Night in Couple's Therapy (Video) Additional executive producers on Season 2 of “Modern Love” include Todd Hoffman
column51: along with Caitlin Roper and Choire Sicha of The New York Times.  Sean Fogel is a producer and Daniel Jones
column53: is a co-producer.  The series is produced by Amazon Studios
column56: and The New York Times.  Read original story Kit Harington

column1: 2021-02-21 11:30:23#world#In the Second Cold War
column2: Religious Americans Must Lead the Way#https://news.yahoo.com/second-cold-war-religious-americans-113023625.html#https://s.yimg.com/uu/api/res/1.2/dxWTVvlevLrns8Qq1sZlPg--~B/aD00NjQ7dz03OTY7YXBwaWQ9eXRhY2h5b24-/https://media.zenfs.com/en/the_national_review_738/7270c03fb95cebb58ec655de3d33d189#en#-0.5994#news.yahoo.com#Last week
column3: Bitter Winter published the first English translation of the Chinese Communist Party’s new “Administrative Measures for Religious clergy
column4: ” set to come into effect on May 1.  First among the measures is the establishment of a comprehensive national database to record and track the state-authorized clergy of the five authorized religions (Protestant Christianity
column8: and Taoism).  Any dissenting member of the clergy not registered in this database will be in immediate violation of the law.  As Nina Shea observes
column9: in order to register in the first place
column10: clergy will have to demonstrate that they “support the leadership of the Chinese Communist Party and support the socialist system. ” Their loyalty to the CCP will then be periodically assessed in a manner similar to the country’s broader social-credit system.  These measures are further evidence of the CCP leadership’s eagerness to avoid the tactical mistakes made by the Soviet Union last century.  The Chinese Communists aren’t trying to extirpate every last trace of theism
column11: thereby inviting the undivided opposition of religious believers and institutions (as the Soviets did with regard to John Paul II’s Vatican).  Instead
column12: they’re attempting to enervate religious opposition to the regime by taming and co-opting domestic religious belief
column13: turning it into another thoroughfare for the regime’s agenda of social control.  For this reason
column14: Chairman Xi has prioritized the “sinicization” of religion in China
column15: all but mandating the prominent presence of his own likeness in every house of worship.  The tactical approach that the CCP has taken toward the Roman Catholic Church is particularly instructive of how party policy on religion differs from that of Communist regimes past (and even present if one considers the Kims in North Korea).  Instead of trying to drive the Catholic Church out of China altogether
column16: the CCP seeks to increase its own influence over the Vatican.  (They’ve taken exactly the same approach toward many other things like American sports leagues
column18: and even capitalism itself. ) On September 22
column20: the CCP signed an agreement with the Vatican — the text of which is still secret — according to which the two parties agreed to “cooperate” in the selection of Chinese bishops.  In practice
column21: this has basically meant that the Chinese have presented their approved candidates to the pope
column23: almost as a formality.  The whole affair reflects very poorly on Pope Francis and the Vatican hierarchy.  The hope was to allow Chinese Catholics worshipping underground to come out of hiding and live out their faith in public; but this “liberation” has been purchased at the price of ceding all control over Chinese Catholicism to a militantly atheist cabal of genocidal communists.  The naïveté of the Vatican in agreeing to such an arrangement has been exposed to the fullest extent by these new “administrative measures”: Article 16 says that bishops in China will be democratically elected through the state-controlled Chinese Patriotic Catholic Association and consecrated by the Chinese Catholic Bishops Conference.  No reference at all is made to the pope or the Vatican
column24: who’ve been completely excised from the process.  The CCP has cemented its sole control over Chinese Catholicism with the formal backing of the Catholic Church itself (the 2018 deal was renewed last year)
column25: leaving Chinese Catholic dissenters from the Party without even the formal backing of their own church.  In other words
column26: this isn’t your grandfather’s evil empire.  The CCP are smarter
column28: and more economically dominant than the Bolsheviks ever were.  And right now
column30: along with the other major religions of the world
column32: something that even Marx himself didn’t think was possible.  As China’s only serious geopolitical rival
column33: the United States also happens to be the most religious country in the developed world and the only country that sees religious liberty as the first and most precious jewel in its constitutional crown.  If any nation on Earth with geopolitical heft is to take serious offense at China’s war on religious freedom
column34: it’s likely to be the U. S.  And yet there appears to be no appetite among the American public for a full-scale geostrategic conflict with China.  Policy proposals for a new Marshall Plan to compete with the CCP’s Belt and Road Initiative aren’t forthcoming in our public conversations.  Worse than that
column35: the U. S.  hasn’t even been able to muster the collective will to offer American visas to Hong Kongers.  The Cold War consciousness that underpinned our enmity toward the Soviets last century is simply not an animating force today
column36: even though Communist China arguably poses an an even greater challenge to the free world than the Soviets did.  The most likely explanation for this has to do with the CCP’s signature tactic
column37: as discussed above: They prefer to co-opt and manipulate people and forces instead of destroying them.  During the last few decades
column38: they’ve done precisely this with respect to free trade and global capitalism.  Chinese producers have gotten their hooks deep into American consumers and have made the Party an indispensable part of the American (and world) economy.  The CCP is deeply involved in our daily lives as consumers in a way that the Soviets never were.  By making American consumers their economic vassals
column39: the Chinese have neutered any appetite for full-scale geopolitical conflict among America’s governing elite
column40: who are terribly aware of what a policy of decoupling would likely mean for their own electoral prospects.  If voters are offered freedom from economic complicity in Communist atrocities in exchange for higher prices
column41: are we sure they’d take the high road? One really has to wonder whether or not the first Cold War would have ended the way it did if the Soviets held sway over prices in the American marketplace.  The Chinese Communists haven’t tried to destroy capitalism.  They’ve prioritized state ownership of the mind and soul over state ownership of the means of production
column42: and they’ve been more than happy to use capitalism to achieve that end.  We in the free world were convinced after the fall of the Soviet Union that economic and political freedom were necessarily joined at the hip.  We therefore sought the liberalization of the global economy in the earnest belief that political freedom would follow.  It never occurred to us that the Communists of the future might not be interested in nationalizing railroads or post offices but in nationalizing childhood
column46: and Jesus Christ — and in using the almighty dollar to do so.  We never considered the possibility that the 21st century could turn out to be the hideous lovechild of Margaret Thatcher and Deng Xiaoping.  Well
column47: to borrow a phrase from Solzhenitsyn
column48: the great truth has now dawned
column49: especially for religious Americans.  We in the free world have made the Chinese Communist Party the most powerful producer and consumer in a global capitalist economy.  In one of human history’s cruelest ironies and most perfidious paradoxes
column50: Xi Jinping now bestrides the world as a Marxist robber-baron
column51: a creature whose existence has eluded our categories of political thought for the last 200 years.  With every new revelation of the CCP’s crackdown on religious believers
column52: religious Americans are faced afresh with the fact that even an innocuous trip to Walmart might amount to an in-kind contribution to the massacre of the holy innocents; that the money we spend on our household goods is going into the pockets of latter-day Neros and Diocletians.  It’s been said that
column54: Americans will have to choose between free trade and free markets
column55: since China’s policy is to make markets unfree.  It’s even more true that
column57: religious Americans will have to choose between free trade and religious liberty
column59: American believers are unwittingly funding the martyrdom of their co-religionists.  Christianity (and most of the world’s great faiths) looks upon the faithful as an indivisible
column61: religious Americans must lead the charge to decouple from China economically.  They know that short-term national economic interests of the United States are worth nothing more than ash and sand when compared with the integrity and communion of the faithful.  If American believers persist in their acquiescence to China’s hold over the American consumer in spite of this knowledge
column62: they shouldn’t be surprised to be greeted with a stunning flash of celestial light the next time they’re on their way to Costco
column63: and with a voice crying out

column1: 2021-02-22 01:41:30#business#Days Before Blackouts
column2: One Texas Power Giant Sounded the Alarm#https://finance.yahoo.com/news/days-blackouts-one-texas-power-014130098.html#https://s.yimg.com/uu/api/res/1.2/EcVbpusCTeKs3EVQYNNeNw--~B/aD0xMzMzO3c9MjAwMDthcHBpZD15dGFjaHlvbg--/https://media.zenfs.com/en/bloomberg_markets_842/acd4f3e823348a0a1d29245224e5f740#en#-0.34#finance.yahoo.com#(Bloomberg) -- Vistra Corp.
column3: one of the largest power generators in Texas
column4: said it warned state agencies days before cascading blackouts plunged millions into darkness that internal forecasts showed electricity demand was expected to exceed supply. Despite the warning
column5: “the coordination and planning by authorities across the broader energy sector were seemingly disproportionate to the severity of the situation
column6: ” Vistra said in an emailed statement late Sunday.  The company didn’t identify which state entities it contacted.  The Electric Reliability Council of Texas is the state’s grid operator
column7: while the Texas Public Utility Commission regulates power generators. Ercot said in a statement its “operating notices incentived all available generation to serve customers” and didn’t immediately comment on the Vistra letter.  Andrew Barlow
column8: an official with the PUC
column9: said he wasn’t privy to any correspondence between the agency and Vistra and referred the matter to Ercot. “Days ahead of this event
column10: Vistra and others forecasted insufficient generation would be available
column11: and we began winter emergency preparations
column12: ” the statement said.  “The warning signs were there
column13: but the public was unaware of the gravity of the situation
column14: which led to people being unable to respond and make the necessary adjustments for their families. ”Read more: How Extreme Cold Turned Into a U. S.  Energy Crisis: QuickTakeAt its peak
column15: more than 4 million Texans were without power over several days of unprecedented cold.  Dozens have perished in the wake of what has now become known as the largest forced power outage in U. S.  history.  Even when electricity was restored as temperatures rose
column16: millions remained without safe drinking water after power outages hit treatment plants and water pumps used to pressurize lines. For more articles like this
column17: please visit us at bloomberg. comSubscribe now to stay ahead with the most trusted business news source. ©2021 Bloomberg L. P. #https://finance.yahoo.com/news/days-blackouts-one-texas-power-014130098.html#UyfBv2dEQ

column4: UN Report Says#https://news.yahoo.com/erik-prince-trump-ally-violated-152611401.html#https://s.yimg.com/ny/api/res/1.2/N44SvlGXrWoT.Z07Gy2pmA--/YXBwaWQ9aGlnaGxhbmRlcjt3PTIwMDA7aD0xMzI5/https://s.yimg.com/uu/api/res/1.2/eoVfQR7SqEZS_DuVW.MLfQ--~B/aD0xOTk0O3c9MzAwMDthcHBpZD15dGFjaHlvbg--/https://media.zenfs.com/en/the_new_york_times_articles_158/3ba9e23688a39b094767fa2ee30f4fd3#en#-0.5267#news.yahoo.com#"NAIROBI
column6: the former head of the security contractor Blackwater Worldwide and a prominent supporter of former President Donald Trump
column7: violated a United Nations arms embargo on Libya by sending weapons to a militia commander who was attempting to overthrow the internationally backed government
column8: according to U. N.  investigators.  A confidential U. N.  report obtained by The New York Times and delivered by investigators to the Security Council on Thursday reveals how Prince deployed a force of foreign mercenaries
column9: armed with attack aircraft
column11: to eastern Libya at the height of a major battle in 2019.  As part of the operation
column12: which the report said cost $80 million
column13: the mercenaries also planned to form a hit squad that could track down and kill selected Libyan commanders.  Sign up for The Morning newsletter from the New York Times Prince
column14: a former Navy SEAL and the brother of Betsy DeVos
column16: became a symbol of the excesses of privatized American military force when his Blackwater contractors killed 17 Iraqi civilians in 2007.  In the past decade he has relaunched himself as an executive who strikes deals — sometimes for minerals
column17: other times involving military force — in war-addled but resource-rich countries
column18: mostly in Africa.  During the Trump administration
column19: Prince was a generous donor and a staunch ally of the president
column20: often in league with figures like Steve Bannon and Roger Stone as they sought to undermine Trump’s critics.  And Prince came under scrutiny from the Trump-Russia inquiry over his meeting with a Russian banker in 2017.  Prince refused to cooperate with the U. N.  inquiry; his lawyer did not respond to questions about the report.  Last year the lawyer
column22: told The Times that Prince “had nothing whatsoever” to do with military operations in Libya.  The accusation that Prince violated the U. N. ’s arms embargo on Libya exposes him to possible U. N.  sanctions
column23: including a travel ban and a freeze on his bank accounts and other assets — though such an outcome is uncertain.  The report raises the question of whether Prince played on his ties to the Trump administration to pull off the Libya operation.  It describes how a friend and former business partner of Prince traveled to Jordan to buy surplus
column24: American-made Cobra helicopters from the Jordanian military — a sale that ordinarily would require U. S.  government permission
column25: according to military experts.  The friend
column27: assured officials in Jordan that he had “clearances from everywhere” and that his team’s work had been approved “at the highest level
column28: ” the report found.  But the Jordanians
column31: forcing the mercenaries to source new aircraft from South Africa.  A Western official
column32: speaking to The Times on the condition of anonymity because he was not permitted to discuss confidential work
column33: said the investigators had also obtained phone records showing that Prince’s friend
column35: made several calls to the main White House switchboard in late July 2019
column36: after the mercenary operation ran into trouble.  The Western official said it was unclear whom Durrant sought to contact
column37: or if he got through.  Contacted through his Facebook page
column38: Durrant declined to comment and referred to a statement he issued to the Australian Broadcasting Corp.  last September.  “We don’t breach sanctions; we don’t deliver military services
column41: ” it said.  The sheer breadth of evidence in the latest U. N.  report — 121 pages of code names
column43: offshore bank accounts and secretive weapons transfers spanning eight countries
column44: not to mention a brief mention of a Hollywood friend of Prince — provides a glimpse into the secretive world of international mercenaries.  Libya began to fracture a decade ago
column45: when the violent ouster of the country’s longtime dictator
column47: set in motion a political crisis that splintered the country into armed factions
column48: many eventually supported by foreign powers hoping to shape the destiny of the oil-rich North African nation.  Eastern Libya is now in the hands of Khalifa Hifter
column49: the powerful militia commander whom Prince agreed to support
column51: as the country was wracked by fighting in 2019.  A one-time CIA asset who returned from exile in Virginia after the fall of Gadhafi in 2011
column52: Hifter rapidly established himself in the eastern city of Benghazi as an aspiring strongman who was determined to blast his way to power if necessary.  In his late 70s
column53: Hifter has relied for years on the United Arab Emirates for funding
column54: armed drones and a range of powerful weapons
column55: according to successive U. N.  reports.  More recently
column56: Hifter has also received backing from Russia
column57: in the form of mercenaries with the Kremlin-linked Wagner Group that has become an integral part of his war machine.  In April 2019
column58: Hifter launched a blistering assault on the capital
column60: but formidable obstacles stood in his way
column61: including newly arrived troops from Turkey supporting the U. N. -backed government.  So Hifter turned to Prince
column62: the U. N.  investigators found.  At a meeting with Hifter in Cairo
column63: 10 days after the start of the campaign to seize Tripoli
column64: Prince made his pitch for the $80 million mercenary operation
column65: the U. N.  inspectors revealed.  Four days later
column67: reversing American policy toward Libya and supporting the assault on Tripoli.  But the mercenary operation turned to disaster just months later.  No sooner had 20 mercenaries arrived in Benghazi in June 2019 — Britons
column69: South Africans and one American — than they became embroiled in a dispute with Hifter
column70: who accused them of failing to deliver promised American-made Cobra helicopters
column71: the report found.  Tensions rose and
column73: the mercenaries bailed out of Libya by boat on an arduous 40-hour journey across the Mediterranean until they reached safety in Malta.  But key elements of the mercenary mission — a cyberwarfare team that arrived separately and several attack aircraft — remained in Libya
column74: the report said.  And the fleeing soldiers of fortune left behind a long trail of paperwork that eventually led U. N.  investigators to Prince.  A PowerPoint presentation shown to Hifter and reproduced in the report lists possible “high value targets” for assassination
column77: and two other Libyan commanders who hold Irish passports
column78: suggesting the mercenaries were ready to hit European Union citizens if necessary.  A welter of contracts detailed in the report show how Prince moved three aircraft into Libya at short notice
column79: transferring one for a nominal sum of $10.  There are also hints of a certain self-regarding bravado inside the group.  The report said that on a trip to Jordan
column81: the friend and former partner of Prince
column82: used the cover name Gene Rynack — close to Gene Ryack
column83: the cowboy pilot played by Mel Gibson in the movie “Air America
column84: ” about a CIA airline that smuggled drugs and weapons during the Vietnam War.  In fact
column85: Prince knows Gibson and hosted him in Abu Dhabi for a couple of days in 2013
column87: a former Marine who worked with Prince at the time.  Prince has been angling for military business in Libya since 2013
column90: Prince supplied the Libyan commander with a private jet
column91: owned by Hong Kong-based Frontier Services Group company led by Prince
column92: and which Hifter used for travel to meetings in Egypt and across the region
column93: the report says.  That same year Prince pitched the European Union on a private military force to patrol Libya’s borders and combat illegal migration.  The Europeans declined.  To the outside world
column94: the mercenaries claimed to be working on a geological survey or an oil and gas project.  The report says that Bridgeporth
column95: a British survey company then owned by Prince
column96: was used to manufacture cover stories — just as the company had been used as cover for previous mercenary operations in South Sudan and Uganda.  Travis Maki
column97: an American pilot who once worked for Bridgeporth
column98: told U. N.  investigators that he flew one of Prince’s planes into Libya just before the operation.  The plane
column100: had previously been used by Prince during his Blackwater days
column101: and is the same model used by Gibson’s character in the movie ""Air America. "" In Libya
column102: it had been fitted with powerful optical sensors that made it a piece of military equipment
column103: the arms inspectors concluded.  In an email
column106: denied the company’s aircraft were used for anything other than surveys
column107: and said that Maki had not worked for the company since 2018.  Prince's Frontier Group
column109: no longer held a stake in the company
column110: he added.  Prince has faced accusations of violating international law before.  In 2012
column111: U. N.  investigators accused his anti-piracy force in Somalia
column113: of “the most brazen violation of the arms embargo by a private security company. ” Whether he will face sanctions as a result of the accusations against him
column115: is highly uncertain.  Prince can no longer rely on allies with the Trump administration to protect him.  At the same time
column116: a senior diplomat at the U. N.  said the Biden administration may be reluctant to penalize an American for breaches of the arms embargo when others are guilty of far worse.  In October
column117: the European Union imposed sanctions on Yevgeny Prigozhin
column118: a wealthy Russian business owner known as “Putin’s chef” for his close ties to the Wagner Group mercenaries fighting in Libya.  But Prigozhin gets only a fleeting mention in the latest U. N.  report — perhaps because investigators
column120: struggled to build a case against him.  On the other side of the fight
column121: the report identifies Turkey — an ally of Libya’s internationally backed government — as a major violator of the arms embargo.  The big question about Prince left unanswered by the U. N.  report is who funded the $80 million mercenary operation he is accused of undertaking.  “He’s been linked to the Trump administration
column122: the Emirati leadership and the Russians
column124: a Libya expert at the German Institute for International and Security Affairs.  “For me
column125: the question is who is tacitly backing him?” Analysts and Western officials said the UAE was the most likely foreign funder of the Libya mercenary operation Prince is accused of launching.  The report points out that the mercenaries had offices
column126: bank accounts and shell companies in the Emirates.  Moreover
column127: the powerful ruler of the Emirates
column129: has long-standing ties to Prince and is probably Hifter’s most important foreign backer.  Last year
column130: the UAE poured tons of weapons into Libya in blatant disregard for the arms embargo
column131: even as Mohammed traveled to Berlin for a major peace conference on Libya
column132: where he posed with European leaders.  As with previous U. N.  investigations
column133: the Emirates refused to cooperate with requests for information about the operation involving Prince and the mercenaries.  “They have yet to respond
column134: ” the report noted.  This article originally appeared in The New York Times.  © 2021 The New York Times Company"#https://news.yahoo.com/erik-prince-trump-ally-violated-152611401.html#RH8fs81cQ

column1: 2021-02-21 09:56:57#science#When 60 Minutes’ Hysteria Nearly Shot Down a NASA Mission to Saturn#https://www.yahoo.com/news/60-minutes-hysteria-nearly-shot-095657185.html#https://s.yimg.com/uu/api/res/1.2/J14op07W_BvPIeKR8sBSKQ--~B/aD02NTg7dz0xMTcwO2FwcGlkPXl0YWNoeW9u/https://media.zenfs.com/en/thedailybeast.com/d20827b66b84336def8e2aea4800ce7f#en#-0.4404#www.yahoo.com#NASA/JPL-Caltech/Space Science Institute via GettyFew impediments could have been more severe.  For a spacecraft to reach the Jovian system with enough speed to eventually achieve orbit around Europa
column2: it had to either launch from a powerful rocket (which NASA lacked
column3: limiting spacecraft to a space shuttle deployment) or be absurdly light (which the required radiation armor rendered impossible).  JPL engineers dashed out hastily written equations in chalk before driving fists against blackboards in fits of despair. Nothing for NASA was ever free… except for gravity assists.  Ordinarily
column4: the agency could compensate for the meager speeds of heavy spacecraft by taking indirect flight paths and using planets encountered along the way to yank and shove the robotic pilgrim outward
column6: or onward.  The laws of physics being immutable
column8: NASA’s orbital dynamicists could do this all day
column9: running the numbers to sling spacecraft precisely
column10: one planet to the next: free propulsion from Isaac Newton.  It was incomparably the best bargain in space exploration. But then television tabloid journalism got involved
column12: while waiting at Cape Canaveral for liftoff
column13: the Cassini mission was beset suddenly by political protest.  Cassini carried three radioisotope thermoelectric generators
column14: which were powered by the decay of plutonium 238.  The plutonium wasn’t of the Back to the Future variety—a disquieting drop of Scary Substance Indeed into a homemade flux capacitor—but rather was stored in a ceramic form
column16: and caked in graphite.  It could not corrode
column20: or dissolve in water.  It was made to withstand not only the explosion of the rocket carrying it
column21: but even a catastrophic reentry into Earth’s atmosphere.  Because it couldn’t vaporize
column23: no one would inadvertently breathe it in and develop superpowers or extra appendages.  In fact
column24: it was designed so that you could even eat the stuff.  The human body could not absorb it. NASA’s Mars 2020 Mission Could Rock Our WorldBut 10 days before three and a half million pounds of rocket thrust put inches between Cassini and Earth
column26: as in 60 Minutes—nearly nailed NASA to the ground.  The CBS TV newsmagazine aired a feature on the soon-set-for-Saturn spacecraft
column27: Steve Kroft starring in the segment.  The correspondent’s opening line: “On October thirteenth
column28: a Titan IV rocket is scheduled to lift off from Cape Canaveral carrying seventy-two pounds of deadly plutonium; enough plutonium
column30: to administer a fatal dose to every man
column31: woman and child on the face of the Earth several times over. ”And it got only worse from there.  Cassini was an afterthought in the story
column32: and interviews from experts were interspersed with comments from… nonexperts
column35: whose contributions—the generous ones! —included lines such as
column38: the right to risk the population’s death or—or injury just for space exploration?”The segment featured a plutonium expert from the Department of Energy stating flatly that even if the rocket
column42: ceramic plutonium blew up on the launch pad
column43: it was literally impossible for the debris to do what protesters said it would.  But just to be balanced
column44: Kroft’s menagerie of doomsayers described in lurid detail what plutonium—not in the form used by NASA
column45: which you could safely sprinkle on your breakfast cereal
column48: you could eat it—could do to the human body.  Among the highlights: “it can produce pulmonary cancer” and “you could have numbers like 100
column49: 000 or more people who develop lung cancer” and “if there is such an explosion
column50: you can kiss Florida good-bye. ”Kroft even found a former NASA employee (“He’s neither a scientist nor an engineer
column52: “but…”) to lament publicly his role in endangering lives for such frivolities as space exploration.  “I feel guilty
column54: ” bewailed the penitent insider. To seal the deal
column55: Kroft intercut the story with snippets of an interview with Wes Huntress
column57: who had presided over the successful landing of Mars Pathfinder only months earlier. “This is from your own environmental impact statement
column58: ” said Kroft to Huntress—the tone of the host solid but affable
column59: his countenance hard but eyes somehow benevolent.  “I want to read you a couple of things from it. ”Huntress was a pioneer in the study of interstellar clouds and one of the world’s foremost experts in planetary exploration
column60: but he was not exactly tabloid-TV material
column61: and after the cavalcade of activists arguing compellingly and without interruption
column62: he seemed less than confident in his responses. Quoted Kroft: “If there’s an accident it talks about
column64: ‘removing and disposing of all vegetation in contaminated areas
column65: demolishing some or all structures and relocating the affected population permanently. ’”“If there should be any such accident
column69: that sounds fairly drastic…” and Kroft waited patiently for Huntress
column70: in possession of rope necessary to hang himself
column72: which 60 Minutes interview subjects always did
column75: the—what they’re probably talking about mostly is—is the damage on site
column76: near the—near—near the launch pad because there’s clearly
column77: when one of these things goes

column80: explaining precisely how Life as We Know It was drawing to a close
column81: and kiss your babies tonight because our foolhardy quest to conquer the cosmos—Saturn! This pointless mission to a gas giant
column82: whatever that meant—will leave mutated survivors fighting for the last canned goods on ransacked store shelves. Worse yet

column89: from Earth [E] to Jupiter [J] for a gravity assist [GA]).  US Air Force security police form a line to thwart protesters demonstrating against the planned Cassini nuclear powered spacecraft launch in front of the security fence October 4
column90: 1997 at Florida's Cape Canaveral Air Force station.  The Cassini is a scientific spacecraft that will travel to Saturn on a five-year journey to orbit the planet and deploy a probe to the surface.  Roberto Schmidt/AFP via Getty The Clinton administration really did not have time for this but dutifully absorbed the panicked letters and optics of protesters grasping concertina-topped chain-link fences on Cape Canaveral’s perimeter
column92: police lined up in body armor and carrying riot shields stared silently
column93: just waiting to—what? Open fire? Brandish batons?Nevertheless
column94: NASA went forward with its reckless rocket launch likely to leave only cockroaches crawling the Earth (or whatever some future species would call this planet)
column96: as they had been for previous launches dozens of times over.  But the message from headquarters to those filing future space missions: if you must launch radioactive material
column97: do not plan trajectories taking the spacecraft back to Earth for a gravity assist.  Nobody needs the headache. Which meant
column99: years-long discussions on potential trade-offs for the Europa Orbiter mission
column100: as it came to be called.  They analyzed other trajectories
column101: other launch vehicles—anything to get more mass for a suitable science return.  What hardware do you make “rad-hard”—impervious to radiation (but expensive) —versus simply wrap in “dumb mass
column103: big blocks of cheap protective shielding? What was the absolute smallest science payload possible? Ultimately
column104: they found a relatively happy medium: a spacecraft that could launch direct and achieve the minimum science required to make a Europa expedition worthwhile
column107: and in 1999 Ed Weiler shot it dead.  Just like that. From THE MISSION

2021-02-21 11:01:13#health#Remembering the lives lost to COVID-19: Carmelina Inchaustegui
column3: of Miami#https://news.yahoo.com/remembering-the-lives-lost-to-covid-19-carmelina-inchaustegui-77-of-miami-110113070.html#https://s.yimg.com/os/creatr-uploaded-images/2021-02/d20a74b0-7384-11eb-b7f8-79f02973d650#en#-0.3182#news.yahoo.com#Carmelina Inchaustegui
column8: following an almost monthlong battle with COVID-19.  She’s among hundreds of thousands of Americans who have lost their lives to the disease since the onset of the coronavirus pandemic in early 2020. Inchaustegui immigrated to the U. S.  from Cuba in the early sixties
column9: shortly after Fidel Castro took control over the island on Jan.  1
column10: 1959.  The Cuban Revolution unleashed the largest refugee flow to the U. S.  in history
column11: and Inchaustegui was one of over a million Cubans who fled the island and came to the U. S.  in search for a better life. #https://news.yahoo.com/remembering-the-lives-lost-to-covid-19-carmelina-inchaustegui-77-of-miami-110113070.html#7E8wEygw4
